image.altText: Rex Airlines

props.synopsis: Regional Australian airline Rex suspends trading on the Australian stock market and the airline's website is no longer taking bookings for flights between metropolitan areas.

title.children: Rex Airlines' future uncertain in wake of ASX trading halt, union says industry is in 'crisis'

image.altText: Houses under construction on a bright, sunny day

props.synopsis: New data issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show the total number of dwellings approved in June fell by 6.5 per cent. Some experts are calling on Australia to adopt more alternative construction models.

title.children: Construction body says Australia will struggle to build 1.2 million new homes if building approvals don't improve

image.altText: Rower Tara Rigney is rowing in a single sculls event.

props.synopsis: Tara Rigney rows for a spot in the single sculls semis, Kyle Chalmers swims in the 100m freestyle heats, Jess Fox returns to the canoe slalom rapids, and the Boomers take on Canada on day four of the Paris Olympics. Follow live.

title.children: Rowers, swimmers and Jess Fox hit the water and Boomers continue their campaign day four in Paris

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Medal tally: Here's where Australia sits heading into day four

image.altText: seine water

props.synopsis: The men's triathlon at the Paris Olympics that was due to take place this afternoon, Australian time, has been postponed because pollution levels in the River Seine remain too high.

title.children: Olympic men's triathlon postponed due to pollution levels in River Seine

image.altText: Kamala Harris, in a beige suite, looks over her shoulders at the top of aircraft stairs

props.synopsis: North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper and Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer are both out of the race to become Kamala Harris's running mate.

title.children: Kamala Harris running mate race narrows, with two more candidates out

image.altText: An aerial shot shows mourners from the Druze minority surrounding five white coffins.

props.synopsis: Israel promised to make Hezbollah pay for the strike in Majdal Shams, but as the war in Gaza drags on it finds itself in a tough position.

title.children: Israel thought two unusual security strategies kept it safe. Here's why they may no longer work

image.altText: Constable Randall Kirk walking in front of two other men wearing a blazer with a police name badge pinned onto it and glasses.

props.synopsis: Queensland Constable Randall Kirk tells an inquest into the Wieambilla shootings he was told to look after himself before asking if he should run.

title.children: Police officer shot at Wieambilla tells inquest he had no option but to run

image.altText: A person takes a photo of the aurora borealis in Vancouver.

props.synopsis: From Australia to the US — here's how the dazzling lights of the aurora australis and borealis were captured in each hemisphere in a rare spectacle.

title.children: Aurora borealis and australis dazzle viewers across the world for three consecutive nights of colourful wonder

image.altText: Four men and a woman pose in an aquatics centre.

props.synopsis: Bob Ballard says he is sorry if his comment on the Australian women swim team, which was criticised for being sexist, caused offence to some people.

title.children: Commentator responds after removal from Olympics over gendered comment on Australian swimmers

image.altText: A firefighter silhouetted against a wall of flame by the side of the road

props.synopsis: The fire sparked by the car is now the sixth largest wildfire in Californian history, across more than 149,000 hectares and only 12 per cent contained.

title.children: California is facing one of the biggest fires in its history. Investigators say one man is responsible

image.altText: A group of three Olympic medals - with silver, gold and bronze left to right - are shown against a dark background.

props.synopsis: Keep up with how many medals Aussie athletes have won today — and where Australia sits on the leaderboard.

title.children: Here's the medal standings for day four of the Olympic Games

image.altText: Tahiti

props.synopsis: It has broken the record for an Olympic venue being the longest distance away from a host city, and Teahupo'o is providing a spectacular backdrop to one of the newest events at the Games.

title.children: Cruise ship accommodation and the 'pile of skulls' — the Olympics surfing venue is one of the most unique in history

image.altText: A large number of police officers standing on a street, speaking

props.synopsis: Two children have been killed and nine more injured during a stabbing attack in England's north-west that one witness likens to a "horror movie".

title.children: 'Worst thing I've ever seen': Two children killed and nine injured in UK stabbing attack

image.altText: Clare Looker appears serious, standing in front of an artwork at a press conference.

props.synopsis: An outbreak of Legionnaires' disease in metropolitan Melbourne has continued to grow, as health authorities race to find the source of infection.

title.children: Melbourne Legionnaire's disease mystery outbreak swells to at least 33

image.altText: A police car parked across a highway

props.synopsis: A 25-year-old man pleads guilty just hours after being charged with trying to kill another man by hitting him with his car and striking him with a hammer, which left the victim's leg severed.

title.children: Perth man pleads guilty to 'heinous' attempted murder of man whose leg was severed in attack

image.altText: Sinead O'Connor wearing a black suit, golden cross necklace, and priest's collar while holding a microphone.

props.synopsis: Shortly after the one-year anniversary of Sinéad O'Connor's death at age 56, an Irish newspaper is reporting a death certificate reveals the singer died from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and bronchial asthma.

title.children: More details about Sinéad O'Connor's cause of death revealed

image.altText: Ariarne Titmus

props.synopsis: As they take their place on the podium after winning a medal, Paris Olympians are being handed a long and skinny box. Here's what's inside.

title.children: Medal-winning athletes are being handed boxes at the Paris Olympics — but what's inside?

image.altText: Paul Dietze

props.synopsis: As dangerous new opioids arrive on Australian streets, experts are calling for more frontline workers to be issued with naloxone, a medicine that can halt drug overdoses.

title.children: Calls for more frontline workers to be armed with drug-overdose-fighting medicine

image.altText: Frost covers the ground as the sun rises behind a tree.

props.synopsis: Sub-zero temperatures have greeted many early risers west of the range in New South Wales and Queensland, with more cold weather expected tomorrow.

title.children: Frosty cold snap across NSW and Qld might yet break some records

image.altText: Trump standing in front of a rally of supporters with his fist raised, wearing a blue suit and red MAGA hat

props.synopsis: The FBI says a local police officer took a photo of gunman Thomas Crooks and sent it to other law enforcement officials at the scene of Donald Trump's Pennsylvania rally before the shooting took place.

title.children: US police photographed Trump shooter more than an hour before assassination attempt

image.altText: Ryan Murphy hugs his wife in the stands. She holds a sign reading "Ryan It's A Girl"

props.synopsis: That's the surprise message that American swimmer Ryan Murphy got from the pool deck as he looked up at his wife in the stands at the Paris Olympics.

title.children: 'It's a girl!' Olympian discovers gender of unborn child while standing on Paris podium

image.altText: James O'Brien smiles while standing in front of a sandy beach in Sydney. He's holding crutches and wearing his prosthetic leg.

props.synopsis: A year since my amputation, I'm marking my "stumpiversary" (as it's sometimes called in the amputee community) and I'm feeling both optimistic and reflective.

title.children: A year ago I became an amputee. Here's how my life has changed

image.altText: An Australian flag flies at the Australian embassy in Jakarta after a bomb attack

props.synopsis: In 2002, Jemaah Islamiah became the most feared terror group in South-East Asia. Now they have publicly renounced violence.

title.children: They were behind the bombings that killed 88 Australians in Bali. Now they've handed over their weapons

image.altText: Michele Bullock, looking at journalists, wearing a light blazer, standing at a podium, during a press conference

props.synopsis: Ahead of its meeting next week, the RBA has effectively talked itself into a corner: should it come good on its threats of a rate hike if inflation comes in hotter than expected, or will it choose to maintain its apparent reluctance to push rates even higher?

title.children: Why the RBA should hold off on rate hikes

image.altText: british sea lord

props.synopsis: Britain's visiting naval chief has declared Australia will eventually operate the world's best anti-submarine warfare (ASW) frigates because a closely linked shipbuilding project in the UK is now "stabilising" after suffering damaging initial setbacks.

title.children: British sea lord assures Australian officials troubled warship program 'stabilising'

image.altText: A woman runs past a police barricade with a fire lit in front

props.synopsis: Demonstrators are protesting outside the presidential palace and toppling down statues following the re-election of Venezuela's president Nicolás Maduro. Here's your breakdown.

title.children: 'We're fed up': Why deadly protests are erupting in Venezuela following the country's election

image.altText: A crowd dressed in black is gathered at a rally

props.synopsis: Israel and Hezbollah last went to war in 2006, but now, with tensions sky high, all-out war looms again amid the Gaza conflict.

title.children: After 18 years on the fringes, the Middle East's most powerful paramilitary group and its biggest foe now sit on the verge of war

image.altText: Two men in rain jackets, walk with a woman who is carrying a child through the mud.

props.synopsis: Local authorities say rescue operations have been hampered after a main bridge collapsed in the region.

title.children: Multiple landslides in India's Kerala state kill at least 41 and injure over 70

image.altText: A man wearing red holds two children, in front of a boat floating on brown water.

props.synopsis: China's southern Hunan province has suffered several days of heavy rain and flooding as remnants of the now-weakened Typhoon Gaemi continue to lash the country.

title.children: Weakened Typhoon Gaemi brings torrential rain to China, death toll rises

image.altText: A graphic of a hand asking for money.

props.synopsis: Australian businesses are paying untold amounts in ransom to hackers but the government hopes to regain some control with a landmark cybersecurity law.

title.children: Most cyber ransoms are paid in secret but a new law could change that

image.altText: Mr Bean in a white tie looking at an old mobile phone with one hand and playing a synthesiser with the other

props.synopsis: Some of the biggest music performances from the Olympic Games, from Torvill and Dean's victorious ice dance to Boléro to the Spice Girls reunion in London.

title.children: Music at that Paris Olympics Opening Ceremony was huge. Here are other memorable music moments in Olympic history

image.altText: Ariarne Titmus and Mollie O'Callaghan smile for a photo together with their silver and gold medals

props.synopsis: It was Mollie O'Callaghan's night in Paris, but alongside Ariarne Titmus, with the gold medal around her neck and the pressure finally released, she was free to create a moment to live long in Australian Olympic folklore.

title.children: With their rivalry for the ages, O'Callaghan and Titmus have reminded Australia there is so much more to come

image.altText: Margaret Kelly holds a red mobility scooter amid dirt and debris from housings being pulled down

props.synopsis: Photojournalist Sean Davey captures the crusade to save Port Melbourne's Barak Beacon Estate, and how a community united to highlight the plight of all public housing tenants.

title.children: At 68, Margaret Kelly was told to move from her home. Instead she led a fight for the right to public housing
